physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long, types on plain paper. The words “Little Review (Margaret) are written in pencil at the top.

div.p: Your very welcome letter came yesterday morning. I am delighted that Richard Aldington’s poems are going into the December number and I have written him to that effect. I remember your telling me that you were going to pay your authors after December. Does this still hold true and may we all expect remuneration in future?

I am sending you a batch of poems. Of course I do not expect you to use them all. I think that if you take one of the longer ones “The Allies,” or "The Ballad of Footmen,”</ you will probably want to return the others. But if you do not like either of these, (in which I think you will be wrong) perhaps you would be so good as to give me a group as the beginning of one of your numbers containing “A Painter on Silk,” “Ely Cathedral,” “Haunted,”>

pb.p: And “Bright Sunlight.” These are so diffdifferent that I think they will go well together. I shall be delighted if you will let me know as soon as possible which of these things you would like to keep because in that case I would know which were released for me to send somewhere else, always an important thing for an author as you know.

Now here is a proposition I should like to make to you. My friend, John Gould Fletcher, who has had a great many poems in “Poetry” and whom I consider one of the very best of the new school, has arrived in America. I am going to take the liberty of giving him a letter to you as he is shortly to go to Chicago to see Harriet Munroe. He wrote me and said that he was going to try to get Harriet Munroe to let him review my book, but I happen to know that she has already done it herself and it is to appear very soon now. It occurs to me that if you are too busy to review it yourself, which it is needless to say I should infinitely prefer, you might find a place for Mr. Fletcher’s review
in one of your numbers. In case this does not meet with your approval or you are so kind as to wish to review the book yourself please let me know at once. Just a “yes” or “no” on a post card will be quite sufficient.

I think you will probably like some of Mr. Fletcher’s poems for your magazine. I am sure that meeting him will be agreeable to you both. I am to see him in New York next week and I will tell him then what to do about the review if you will let me know at once.
